Legend
Directions
This is a simulation of "launching" a non-rotating sphere with variable surface roughness. First, select the surface roughness of the sphere from the drop-down menu titled "Surface roughness \( \frac{ \Large{ \varepsilon } }{ D } \)". The term \( \frac{ \Large{ \varepsilon } }{ D } \) represents the depth of the imperfections (\( \large{ \varepsilon } \)) as a fraction of the sphere diameter (\( \small D \)). Next, choose a launch angle and launch velocity using the sliders, and press "Launch". The trajectory of the sphere is shown on the bottom-left plot, and the drag coefficient as a function of Reynold's number is shown on the bottom-right plot. Each time you launch a sphere, its trajectory will remain drawn on the plot until you press "Clear plot". This way, you can compare different trajectories side-by-side. For information about the equations used in this simulation, press "Details". For information about the author and LearnChemE, press "About".
